thread.title: Rimon adds financial clout to start-ups with seed fund
thread.title_full: Rimon adds financial clout to start-ups with seed fund | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Rimon adds financial clout to start-ups with seed fund
text:
Rimon Advisory, a Sydney-based consultancy that works with entrepreneurs to commercialise their ideas with strategic advice and government grants, is today launching Rimon Investments, a fund it says will back up to 10 early-stage tech ventures over the next 24 months.
Rimon director Lior Stein told The Australian his primary objective with the new fund was to build relationships with individual entrepreneurs and encourage them to innovate on a global level.
“The point of this initial fund is to invest in early stage seed rounds, between $30,000 and $200,000, but there is the ability for our investors to add further capital too if the need arises,” Mr Stein said.
He said Rimon helped start-ups in a variety of ways, including offering a “virtual management team”, which effectively allows an external person to perform functions such as bookkeeping or marketing, allowing the entrepreneur to double down on their product. He added that the fund initially had $1 million to play with.
Joining Brad Shofer as founding investors are Gary Burg, resident director and co-founder at Global Capital Holdings, as well as capital markets expert Neil Hessen, angel investor Michael Kadoury and former Investec chief executive Sam Leon.
The first company to receive seed investment from Rimon is Premonition — a software company aiming to disrupt the logistics industry with a technology platform called Foodbank Local.
Co-founder Brad Lorge said Foodbank Local used artificial intelligence and real-time data to connect donors and charities and improve logistics in the foodbanking sector. An app allows donors to snap and share a photo of their food, and charities can then browse what’s available and choose what they need, with the platform handling allocation, scheduling and routing behind the scenes. It has partnered with several major supermarket and charity groups.
“We realised we needed a long-term, sustainable approach to building this technology,” he said.
“We needed the capital to invest in a longer-term vision, something that would have a longer impact and we needed a group of partners to join us on that quite ambitious journey.
“Brad (Shofer) has read the winds better than almost everyone in Australia, having founded MYOB and then becoming an early investor in Xero, he’s been incredible for our business.”
According to Mr Stein, Rimon Investments has four start-ups in its pipeline but is looking to meet entrepreneurs to invest in.
